Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I glanced at my phone on the passenger seat, the screen lighting up with a message from my daughter: “Don’t forget, Mom, we’re all counting on you to help organize the family dinner this weekend!” The family holiday was always my responsibility, and everyone expected me to keep the tradition alive, to call each relative and make sure no one felt left out. But as I drove my taxi through the city, the meter ticking, I knew I couldn’t just pull over and make calls. My passengers expected a safe, smooth ride, and I was determined to follow every traffic law, especially with the roads so clear and tempting for a quick text at a red light. My heart tugged between the warmth of my family’s expectations and the duty I owed to my passengers and the rules of the road. The phone buzzed again, and I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me, each demanding my attention, each unwilling to wait.
